awd_titl_txt: Workshop:  Using Narrative as Sociolegal Method to Advance Professional Learning and Diversity in the Academy
awd_abstract_narration:
The project seeks to bring together interdisciplinary scholars who focus on law and society in order to explore how professional failures can be integrated into models for professional success. The academic job market, the tenure and promotion process, attempts to move into full-time administration, publication and other realities of academic life yield stories of success that are often passed on in mentoring and professional development workshops. It is relatively rare, however, to confront and share the many more instances of failure that occur in any given career. Failures are typically hidden and can even become part of a destructive identity of shame or secrecy.  How might such stories be transformed and integrated into a holistic approach that enables scholars, teachers and administrators to develop in relation to stories that present fuller pictures of professional life? The workshop will integrate law and social science with psychological research to advance theories about how cognitive biases affect the understanding of how to resolve problems. It will broaden participation across several scientific disciplines that are challenged by failures to understand interdisciplinary work, the limited breadth of knowledge and experience of women and men of all races and ethnicities, full- and part-time professors at different career stages, students and practitioners, and parents and other caregivers. The goal is to formulate and disseminate initial conclusions designed to be the basis for an ongoing conversation through traditional and newer platforms (such as online blogs). This discussion will inform many disciplines and industries about the significance of recognizing loss, error and failure as the keys to individual and institutional success. In short, this workshop will seek to understand achievement in the academy by examining loss, error, and failure. 

The workshop will explore the idea that the traditional view of achievement is warped by survivorship bias. Professionals often hear advice from those who have succeeded that then offer advice based on those successes. Individuals receiving such advice then tend to attribute outcomes to their own individual efforts rather than to institutions and structures outside their control. The traditional approach is blind to the impact of structures of power such as those that create challenges to underrepresented scholars. However, it also ignores the ways in which narratives that include tales of failure can provide enormous opportunities for structural, institutional and personal change.  The workshop will integrate sociolegal scholarship on failures of law with the psychological and sociological literatures on survivorship bias.

Advancement through Narrative:Understanding and Navigating Success and Failure in the Academy.National Science Foundation (SES-1643084)University of California Washington Center, October 12-13, 2017, Washington, DC, 19 participants in addition to organizers

Story Prompts about Failure and Success in Academia Used in the Workshop:

Evaluating the Triad: Research, Teaching, and Service
Universities are increasingly using metrics to evaluate faculty on research, teaching, and service contributions. People and organizations often try to produce u what supervisors measure and reward, though that can lead to perverse outcomes. How does your university evaluate faculty across the triad? How have evaluation and reward affected your work life and practices, such as allocating time and setting priorities, choosing research topics and practices, choosing pedagogies mentoring, and contributing to the collective work of the profession? What obstacles have you faced? Where have you persisted? Where has it been (or would it have been) wiser to stop and move on to something else?

Challenging The Model of the Ideal Worker: Care Work and Beyond
The concept of the “ideal worker” and notions of professionalism have their origins in a largely male workforce and posit an employee who has a single-minded commitment to the work of the organization, able-bodied for work and free of commitments. These assumptions have not changed significantly despite the increasing visibility of claims concerning disabilities, equity, difference, and commitments to home and community. How has your professional trajectory been affected by the ideal worker model? How have you managed to balance the needs of health, community, children, parents, and partners with the requirements for professional advancement? Has your institution facilitated or hindered this balance? How can we understand our personal and professional selves more holistically? How can the problems we encounter be addressed in our professional lives?

Gatekeeping: Hiring, Tenure, and Promotion
In the “buyer’s market” that is contemporary academia, well-trained, qualified, and eager PhDs outnumber precious few tenure track positions. The myth of meritocracy, the adjunct workforce, tenure and promotion processes, and the myriad publication issues, are just a few of the gatekeeping challenges that we face. What have been your experiences with search committees, as applicant and/or the committee member? What does the gatekeeping process looks like at your institution, and to what effect? How are hiring, tenure, and promotion decisions made? What have been your experiences with research publication? How might your story inform changes to academic gatekeeping?

Chilly Climate and Implicit Bias
Implicit bias is an integral part of how people manage a surplus of information. In the academy, the notion of a “chilly climate” aggregates various forms of bias permeating decision-making. Indeed, we ourselves often disregard bias as a factor complicit in our professional fortunes as we attribute our shortcomings to individual rather than systematic, institutional failings. In addition, part of the bias may be not knowing that women may be less likely than men to respond to setbacks by adapting to institutional incentives. What stories can you tell about the chilly climate and implicit bias, and how it has affected your career trajectory? How do the identity categories to which we identify—and to which others label us—affect our experience with and reaction to bias? How do our experiences help us devise approaches to addressing individual and institutional bias and to changing the culture and decision making processes in the academy?

The recent explosion of lawsuits about sexual harassment have once again raised the concern that women early in their careers are sometimes discouraged at work for very blunt and explicit reasons.
